awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides partial support for participants in the 2022 East Coast Operator Algebra Symposium (ECOAS), which will be held October 22-23, 2022 on the Michigan State University campus in East Lansing, MI. The symposium expects between fifty and seventy participants, including many graduate students and postdocs. This will be the nineteenth annual meeting in the East Coast Operator Algebra Symposium series. The first meeting was held at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, TN in the Fall of 2003, and since then, meetings have been held each Fall. 

The conference focuses on operator algebras (C* and von Neumann algebras) and noncommutative geometry, with applications to a wide range of areas, including ergodic theory, number theory, representation theory, and mathematical physics. The ECOAS enables participants to become acquainted with the forefront of research in operator algebras and noncommutative geometry and neighboring areas, while also providing early-career researchers with the opportunity to present their own work and to network and interact with each other as well as with more experienced researchers. Additional information can be found at the conference website: https://users.math.msu.edu/users/banelson/conferences/ECOAS.html

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The nineteenth East Coast Operator Algebras Symposium (ECOAS) was held at Michigan State University on October 22-23, 2022. The conference focuses on operator algebras (C* and von Neumann algebras) and noncommutative geometry, with applications to a wide range of areas, including ergodic theory, number theory, representation theory, and mathematical physics. Consequently, it an important annual conference in the field of operator algebras. It also emphasizes participation by early career researchers (particularly graduate students and postdocs) through speakind and funding priorities. Their attendance allows them to meet senior mathematicians in the area, start collaborations, and learn about recent advances in the field. The plenary speakers, affiliations at the time of the conference, and their talk titles are listed below:

  • Konrad Aguilar (Pomona College): The quantum Gromov-Hausdorff distance and the Gromov-Hausdorff propinquity
  • Samantha Brooker (Arizona State University): Pullback diagrams of relative Toeplitz graph algebras
  • Quan Chen (Ohio State University): K-theoretic classification of inductive limit actions of fusion categories on AF-algebras
  • Changying Ding (Vanderbilt University): Properly proximal von Neumann Algebras
  • Magdalena Georgescu (University of Victoria): Cuntz-Pimsner algebras arising from C*-correspondences over commutative C*-algebras
  • Benjamin Hayes (University of Virginia): Property (T) and strong 1-boundedness for von Neumann algebras
  • Lara Ismert (Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University): Quantum graphs and their infinite path spaces
  • Arundhathi Krishnan (University of Waterloo): Markovianity and the Thompson Group F
  • Michael Montgomery (Dartmouth College): Building finite dimensional representations of fusion algebras with biunitaries
  • Samantha Pilgrim (University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa): Large-Scale Dynamics and Geometric Group Theory
  • Hui Tan (University of California, San Diego): Spectral gap characterizations of property (T) for II_1 factors

The speakers included a mix of senior researchers, early career researchers, and postdocs. There were 6 women speakers and 7 speakers total from underrepresented groups. Overall, there were 64 participants.

Leftover funds from the ECOAS award were used to support graduate students who attended the twentieth ECOAS held at Purdue University.

 


Last Modified: 01/23/2025
Modified by: Brent A Nelson
